captions.text: So today we're going for Korean Massages
[porn music]
Not that kind of massage!  We're going for a foot massage
[porn music]
Foot massages aren't sexy!
[porn music]
Are you just going to say that after everything I say?
[porn music]
Spudgy in a bikini!
[porn music]
Uggh.  Alright, let's just get massages.  Uggh
[Music that isn't porn music.  Relaxing, cool music]
One of the most popular things to do in Korea is something called Dr. Fish
And it's a little bit odd to explain so we're just going to show you
[more of that relaxing music.  Oh yeah.  So nice]
So now we're done with our foot soak and our fish nibbling
and now we're gonna get our foot massages done.  Wish us luck!
[terrible, scary music, meant to match the terrible pain we're experiencing]
WORST PAIN EVER.
Now, you might be saying to yourself "Martina's a big baby"
But, trust me, I've broken a lot of bones, and I've never shed a tear over it
but I shed tears during this foot massage.
And you might say, "Simon's a big guy"
[simon roaring like a dinosaur]
But even Simon was whimpering like a baby
[simon crying like a baby]
Now, you might be thinking to yourself, "okay, this was a fluke"
"they went to some really terrible place and they had terrible foot massages"
But that is not the case.  We've had several different massages in Korea,
We've done back massages, full-body massages, we've done foot massages and scalp massages
ranging from 20 bucks to 200 bucks.  And every single time we go, we get beaten
We just get beaten.  So, I'm not sure if it's because they think foreigners
you know, they gotta be extra rough with us, or if it's just the style
But, either way, I suggest avoiding it, unless you like pain,
or, check it out, maybe dare your friends,
and then send us an email agreeing with us about how painful it was,
*sigh* so traumatic.  *whimpers*
[music]

comments.author: dominique malig

comments.text:
This is coming quite late since the video is quite awhile back. This looks 
like a foot reflexology massage. Apparently, there are acupressure points 
all over your feet that corresponds with the internal organs. What I 
understand from my therapist, coz I go get myself tortured regularly, that 
if the spot they press or rub hurts, it means that the corresponding organ 
is not in its best shape. I feel it's quite effective as I always sleep 
like a baby that same night, feel a lot better the next day, and will 
definitely go for Number 2 if I've been feeling constipated before getting 
tortured. =D﻿
comments.author: Qiuru Tan

comments.text:
hmmm.. i can say i've experienced a massage of any kind in Korea (i've

got?? ﻿
comments.author: Rox Hottest

comments.text:
I'm currently living in Korea and have tried the Dr. Fish and only the 
fish. The fishes were bigger. It was a cool but weird sensation, especially 
when they're nibbling on the tips of your toes.
I'd like to try a foot massage, just for the experience.
I have friend who tried a full body massage, she felt she was molested. Her 
masseuse (an old woman) was massaging her entire front. Of course, I 
laughed when she told me.﻿

comments.author: Helen Lee (Hye-ryeong)

comments.text:
I hate massages here in Korea!!!! They are awful! Even the scrubs you can 
get at a jimjilbang can become like borderline flesh flaying. They took off 
one of my moles once, that's how bad it can be. Also,what reason could 
anyone possibly have to get their stomach massaged?! Answer is none! But 
they still tried it on me once. So awful... so traumatizing. I miss my 
Massage Envy membership back in the states and my monthly Swedish massage 
with light and relaxing movements. No more having fingers stuck in pressure 
points that only a ninja would know, please! I think all masseuses here 
must be ninja's... ﻿

comments.text:
When I was in Turkey my hotel had a women-only spa in the basement 
(sketchy, I know, but actually reputable). I decided to get a "Medical 
massage". Not only did my friend see me naked (and vice versa) because we 
received our baths in the same space, but I got BEATEN and stretched to the 
point that I thought my arms were going to rip off. Meanwhile in Canada, I 
just get these wimpy little "relaxing" massages that don't accomplish 
anything :P
comments.author: Julia Meadows

comments.text:
When I would go for foot massages in China I found the girl massueses would 
beat the hell out of you, but the guy massueses always asked if they were 
causing you pain. If you said yes they would lessen the pressure they used. 
I never went to an actual massuese in Korea, but I did go to a Dr. Fish 
cafe. At that location you could sit for hours with the Turkish or Chinese 
fish as long as you bought something to drink. It was awesome. I miss those 
fish. Since I left Korea my eczema is back.

comments.author: snoobinzzz

comments.text:
Even deep tissue massages should not hurt that much. I think a lot of 
people are under the misconception that "if it hurts, it's working." But 
that's not true. A massage is supposed to work out trigger points and relax 
the muscles in your body in order to eliminate pain. If it hurts that much, 
your body is going to tense up even more and make the massage completely 
useless. There can be a little pain, but pain that makes you cry is not 
good...
comments.author: Rebecca Manuel

comments.text:
My aunt does massages for a living and all the pressing and pounding are 
related to pressure points of the foot that are connected to the different 
parts of the rest of the body, if it hurts, then it means you're got 
problems regarding that area of the body. She gave me a foot massage and I 
screamed so hard I lost my voice after two days and my feet were swollen ;[ 
not enjoyable but they're supposed to make you healthier
